text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Thank you all for joining us. We will be discussing the important
question, is big tech too big?

But before we turn it over to
our distinguished debaters, we want to know what
all of you think.

If you could all just take out your
phones, if you haven't done so already, scan this QR code and just
quickly vote on the proposition.

Do you think big tech is too big?
Do you not? Or are you unsure? We'll also have you vote at
the end to see which team wins.

That'll be exciting.
So just the QR code there.

At BiGS, we really believe in fostering
thoughtful discussion and debate on complex and contentious issues,
which today is a really good example of.

But we really couldn't have done this
without the support of Steve Klinsky,

who was an MBA grad in 1979,
and a law school grad in 1981,

and his family and his
wife, Maureen, as well. They were really interested in
fostering reasoned and structured

debate on campus, and this
 is a great example of that. Without further ado, please join me
in welcoming Professor Debora Spar,

Senior Associate Dean for
Business in Global Society, who will moderate today's debate. [APPLAUSE]

Thank you all for being here. We are super excited to have
this inaugural BiGS debate.

Today is an opportunity
to argue and fight

and get into heated conversation, not just for the fun of
watching these brilliant people

get into some heated debates,
but more importantly, to underscore the point,
as Drew just mentioned,

that there are many
things in our world today, including really big, critical,
maybe even existential things,

about which reasonable
people may disagree. The source of the disagreement
is not because any of these

apparently reasonable people, in fact,
are unreasonable or evil or misinformed;

but because the world is a
complicated place, and the issues that we all care about are complicated
to understand and to unpack.

Even some of the smartest and most
well informed and knowledgeable people

bring their own viewpoints and
their experiences and maybe their own curated sets of facts to what
would appear to be the same questions.

The immediate goal for this afternoon
is to resolve in the next 90 minutes,

one of the toughest and most
consequential issues facing US business and US society today:
is big technology too big?

The longer term goal of this series,
though, is to engage and demonstrate

one of the central objectives
of Harvard Business School, and what I think should be
one of the central objectives

and even more importantly
perhaps, to change one's mind as a result of engaging with these
issues and with these controversies.

We hope to get some good
fights today, as I said, and we hope this is the first in what
will be a long series of BiGS debates.

Anyone who has further ideas for the
next debate, which will be in the fall, let me or Drew or
anyone on the team know.

Let me just begin with a few really
quick statistics to set the stage. As of today, the US Magnificent
Seven, which you all know is

Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft,
Amazon, Meta, Nvidia and Tesla, holds a combined market
value of $15 trillion.

That's about one
third of the S&P 500, or around one quarter of
the entire US stock market.

To put that in global perspective,
these seven companies together

are worth more than the entire
economies of Japan, Germany or India,

and they come close to China. 2024, these firms saw their stock
prices surge on average by 63%,

which accounted for more than half
the gain of the S&P for that year.

Which raises the question we're dealing
with today, is big tech too big,

or is it precisely the right size to
drive growth, innovation and wealth?

To unpack this question, we are incredibly
lucky to have a wonderful set of debaters.

Most of them will be well known to you. I will just give you the very quick,
sort of big picture of their bios.

To my immediate left
is Jonathan Kanter. Jonathan is the former Assistant Attorney
General for the Antitrust Division

of the US Department of Justice. He has been living and
breathing these questions.

He served from 2021 to 2024, during which
time he reshaped antitrust enforcement

in terms of its focus, and filed
landmark lawsuits against the tech giants
Google and Apple,

along with less high profile but
arguably equal important firms such as Live Nation, Visa,
Simon and Schuster, and Adobe.

Prior to serving the Biden
administration, he worked at the FTC, a number of major law firms.

He will be arguing for the
proposition that big tech is too big. On that side, he will be
joined by Professor Timothy Wu,

who is the Julius Silver Professor
of Law Science and Technology at Columbia Law School. Tim has often been
described as the architect

of the Biden administration's
antitrust agenda. He has been working in
this space for decades now,

coined the term ‘net neutrality’,
and is the author of many books, including The Curse of Bigness.
So we know what side he's going to be on.

On the other side of
the small table there, arguing against the proposition
that big tech is too big,

we have Gary Cohn
and Jason Furman. Jason Furman is the Aetna Professor
Of The Practice Of Public Policy,

jointly appointed at
the Kennedy School and the Department of
Economics here at Harvard. He was chair of the Council of Economic
Advisers in the Obama administration,

and played a key role in advising President
Obama and shaping his economic policy.

In addition to co-teaching Harvard's
iconic course Principal Of Economics,

he's the senior fellow at
the Peterson Institute, and served recently as chair of the
Digital Competition Expert panel in the UK,

designed to help that country revisit
and revise its competition policy. Last but not least, Gary Cohn.

Gary is currently
Vice Chair of IBM. He served previously as Director
of the National Economic Council

in the first Trump administration, where he led the administration's
economic policy agenda, with a focus on

successful efforts to grow the economy,
create jobs and increase wages. Prior to his time in the government,
Gary was at Goldman Sachs

for over 25 years, where he
served as President and COO. He began his career at US Steel,

and sits on a number of corporate
boards, advises the FDIC, and is deeply involved in supporting
NYU Langone and the NYU Tandon School.

We couldn't ask for a better
group; they are ready to fight.

Here is very quickly how things will
proceed for the next 85 minutes or so. We have asked each debater to present
five minutes of opening arguments.

After each side has finished their
arguments, each debater will have

three minutes to rebut what
they heard the other side say. Then I will try and pull out sort
of the most contentious pieces

of their statements, we'll get them
to fight a little bit more directly, and then we will turn things over
to the audience for questions.

We have a number of pre-selected questions
from students sitting in the audience here, and if time permits we'll open
it up a little bit more broadly.

Then we will have closing statements,
then we will ask you all to vote again.

Remember, the goal of the exercise
is not just to see which side wins,

but which side convinces more
of you to change your minds.

Before I turn things over to Jonathan,
who is going to be our first debater, I would like to present to you
our preliminary vote results.

Thank you, Drew.
Ooh, that's a little surprising. Is big tech too big?

Yeses got 70% of the votes; so you guys
have a little bit of an uphill battle.

Nos got 18%. Do not want to answer got 12%, so there
are your swing votes there to go after.

But we will start first
with the yes side. Jonathan, please tell us
why big tech is too big.

As any good lawyer would say with those
numbers, we rest to the defendants.

Take a journey with me
back a few months ago. It's January 2025, the President Elect
is getting prepared for inauguration.

It's cold in Washington,
winter in Washington, and the President Elect decides
to break from tradition.

Instead of having the inauguration
outside of the Capitol steps, the President Elect says, “I want to
have it inside the Capitol rotunda.”

Here you have this, and you can
imagine this in your mind's eye, inside the rotunda you have
the President, nice and warm.

Outside, you have a lot of people,
I won't say how many, but a lot. Not the biggest crowd
ever, I think.

And it's cold. The rank and file,
the people who supported the President because they believed him, are
cold outside celebrating the day.

Inside the rotunda, cozy and
warm, right there in the front alongside the President's family,
in front of the incoming cabinet,

are the CEO and founder of
Google, CEO of Apple, Mark Zuckerberg from Meta,
and whatever Elon Musk is.

That is too much power. People need to be physically but
more important, more focally,

inside the rotunda. When I think about whether
companies have too much power, I think across three
different dimensions.

Do they have too
much political power? Too much power over the
direction of our society? Do they have too
much economic power?

And are they using their money to
reinvest back into the economy? And third, do they exert too much
power over others in the ecosystem?

So let's unpack that.
Political power. Not only are they in the
rotunda, we are here in 2025,

given all the information we
collect, we still do not to this day have comprehensive privacy
reform, any legislation.

There are no lines on the road, not for lack of trying and not
for lack of partisan agreement. It's because big companies have so much
political power they can lobby against it.

They influence and control what
people see, what people think, billions, five companies
controlling billions.

over $500 billion of money that
is parked on the sidelines,

that is not being reinvested
back into the economy. From 2020 to 2023,
I think estimates are about

the Mag 7 spent over $700
billion in stock repurchases.

Again, money that is not being
reinvested back into the economy in terms of innovation and jobs.

That is a multiple higher
than what these companies spent in research
and development.

A lot of the capex now, among the
Mag 7, are paying each other, whether it's paying Nvidia for chips,

or Google paying Apple over $20
billion a year for search defaults.

Okay, now let's take a look at
the control they have over others. This is something that
really resonates with me

due to my former role at
the Antitrust Division. These companies are so big,

they function as unaccountable
regulators of their industries. They are not innovating by
making their products better.

They are protecting their monopoly position
by making other people's products worse.

What do I mean by that? They're going out and saying,
I'm going to spend $20 billion,

and in exchange for that $20
billion you company have to agree not to work with somebody else.

I'm going to make it so that you
can't offer a buyer a lower price,

because I'm going to penalize you on
my shopping platform if you do that. I'm going to go and I'm going to
say is one of these companies,

that if you want to charge
your app at a lower price,

or put a link to your own
website inside of your app, I'm going to forbid you
for doing that because

someone might click on that
link and pay less money. I can give you examples like this
all day, they're in our lawsuits.

That is not investing to
make your product better. That is not taking the money
that's sitting on the sidelines.

That is not using your political power to
invest in development and entrepreneurship.

It's too much power. We need more competition to
make sure they are doing better,

and to make sure we can realize
the benefits of innovation. I'm here at Harvard Business
School, I believe in you.

I believe in the next
generation of entrepreneurs who can come up with
that better idea. I believe in the next
generation of entrepreneurs

who could build a better product
and who can maximize terminal value, not just by selling to the large companies,
but by displacing them all together.

Thank you. We are at time.
Thank you. Jason, over to you.

First argument against the
proposition that big tech is too big. If you had invited me to do
this debate five years ago,

I might have actually been
happy to be on that side. When I say happy to be on that
side, it's maybe 70/30 on that side.

Now I'm happy to be on this side, and I'm
happy to be on this side more like 70/30. If your answer to this question is a
definitive yes, or a definitive no,

and if you've had that same
answer year after year after year, you're just not paying attention and
you're not looking at the evidence.

Why have my views evolved? 5 or 10 years ago, I thought
 we had several companies

that had impregnable network
effects, impregnable scale,

that would make it impossible
for anyone else to come along. Then TikTok came along and displaced
an awful lot of what Meta was doing.

Then Twitter grew. It turned out,
when Facebook tried to create,

when Meta tried to create its own
version of a social network like Twitter, it just wasn't as good
in terms of its features,

and as a result it
hasn't been successful. When Google had an enormous,
enormous lead in terms of data and AI,

they actually used their really deep
research budget to publish a paper

on the Transformers Architecture,
a paper that was publicly available,

and then other companies, most
notably OpenAI, used that research

that was produced by that
company to create something that I wouldn't be surprised if fully replaces
Google search in a couple of years.

It turns out, being the incumbent is a
little bit less good than I thought it was. There was more competition.

More competition in social networks,
and especially and most importantly, it wasn't like you could take
your lead in the first sphere

and translate it into
the second sphere. We've seen OpenAI,
we've seen Anthropic, and then with even less money
going into it we've seen DeepSeek.

There's more competition in
this space than I had realized.

The second thing is,
why are these companies big? They're big for two reasons.

The main reason is that people like their
products, they're good at what they do. When they become less good at what they
do, they actually become less big.

That's what we might end up
seeing with Google search if they can't keep up with the
way that OpenAI is searching.

Bigness isn't a good or a bad thing
inherently, it's why are you big?

And that's most of the reason. Now, some of the reason is some of
the conduct that they engage in,

some of the acquisitions
and some of the behavior. Jonathan brought a terrific case
against Google, and I largely agreed

with that case and largely agreed
with the judge's decision on it. But then that gets to the last thing,
which is, so you're bothered by

some of the aspects of bigness,
is the solution worse than the problem?

And here's where I'm torn. I read what the Justice Department
wanted to do with Google,

and it wanted to make a
lot of people use Bing as their search engine
instead of Google. Bing is something consumers consider
a worse search engine than Google.

It's a little bit of a speculative theory
that if we push more people over to Bing, eventually Bing will get better,
and eventually they'll be better off.

But I think ultimately, we can't have
some sort of grand falutin theory about how we want
to redo the world.

We have to defer a lot to people
and to the choices that they make, and pushing people over to
that would be problematic.

Finally, the other thing that's
changed over the last five years is the salience of the
geopolitical aspect of this issue,

and in particular, of the incredible
importance of the competition with China,

and the incredible contrast between
the success of the United States, where we have these Magnificent
Seven, and Europe,

which would love nothing more than to
have seven companies like the seven

that we have that started and were
nurtured here in the United States.

Here too, there's some complications. More competition, more innovation
is good for our geopolitics.

But in general, why you would want to
hobble, especially when it comes to AI,

and that was something where, when the
Justice Department said that part of their remedy was basically breaking
up Google's AI from Google's search,

so they couldn't use their search
information to improve their AI. I thought the people that were
probably most excited about that

were people sitting in
Beijing, who thought, with their lesser concern
about some of these topics,

they would be nurturing something
that was more competitive. There's a lot more
competition in this space.

The reason these companies are big
is because consumers like them. And if you tried to break
them up and solve them,

many of your problems
would still be there, some of them would act
actually be even worse.

Thank you. Tim? Well, thanks. Well, I'm glad, listening carefully
to what Jason had to say,

I’m glad to say he's basically on
our side in the sense that he agrees and is forced to acknowledge
that in order for us to have

the best tech industry in the world,
it has to be a competitive tech industry, and that in fact, holding the feet
of the major tech firms to the fire,

forcing them to compete, forcing them
not to pay off their competitors, like Google was trying
to do with Apple,

is actually in the interest
of the United States. Let me back up a little bit and
start with a few points that we know

from the history of the tech
industry and history of monopoly. Monopolists often start off as great
companies, very popular, good products.

That's usually how they get there. But as time goes on, they tend
to be and become fat and lazy.

In other words, they tend
 to become complacent, they tend to rely on products and
business models that are tested,

and they increasingly begin to
see that there are advantages to becoming a partner with government
or investing in other forms

of barriers to entry to prevent
them from being challenged. All of this is stuff that both
Jason and Gary know well.

While it's still relatively early, the fact
is that the tech companies are on their way

and have every sign of becoming the
next Boeings of the United States. They started with great products.

They're incredibly innovative
and have large amounts of scale. I think all of that
is very important.

But we are starting to see in ways little
and small, whether it was, as we said, the various little ways in which
they find ways to pay off or buy

or pay not to compete, in the ways that the tech industry
is suddenly taking a liking

to government contracts, to influence
of government over government – all the signs that the tech
industry is on a path becoming

more and more like the Defense
Military Industrial Complex, a situation where the companies realize
that it's easier and better not to compete,

and easier and better to both
rely on government contracts and lack of competition
to maintain an easy life.

That is why my part
of the thesis is that big tech has got too big
for its own interests.

If we want to wind back a little bit and
talk about the geopolitical aspects of this let's turn back to the 1970s for a moment.

During that period, the United
States was dominated technologically by two companies, IBM and AT&T.

Both of them were large companies,
monopolies in their spheres. Both of them, at one point,
had been incredibly innovative

and had dazzled people
with their innovations. But by the ‘70s and ‘80s,
they were getting older,

and they were challenged by an
overseas geopolitical rival, Japan, which was then considered to be the
most advanced threatening country

to the United States based on its
technology and based on the fact that it had a government that was supporting
its tech giants at the time, NTT and NEC.

What did the United States do? Did we say, oh no, these companies
are so big that they need our support,

and they are our national champions that
we are going to defend at all costs? No. We broke up AT&T,
we sued IBM in a long lawsuit

which forced them to unbundle
software and forced them to make room for the rise of the
personal computer industry.

The result of these policies was the rise
of a whole new generation of companies, including Apple, Microsoft,

and ultimately much later, the tech
industry after the Microsoft lawsuit.

My point is that it has been a successful
US policy to constantly force competition

onto the tech industry through
antitrust and through other policies, to make sure that it stays competitive,
that it does not become the next Boeing,

that it does not become
the next General Motors, that it does not become one of
these industries that’s just

denominated by a few
companies that never leave. I think our policies have worked. I think the reason we are the
world's dominant tech power

is because we have always forced
our tech sector to compete, and we've never let them
get away with the excuse

that we're the national champions of
the United States, or we need scale. It's always the same story, we need
scale and monopoly to be great.

We need to pursue
what we've always done and that which has worked
best in the tech industry, promote innovation and find
the next little Microsofts,

little Apples, little
Googles, little Facebooks, and give them room
to do their thing. Thank you. Finally, Gary.

Could we talk about how
that worked out for IBM? I'm going to bring that up, because
I'm not sure looking at the history

50 years later it might look like
the best thing the US government did for a lot of companies around the
world, but we won't go there.

I'm the nonacademic in this room, and
I know I'm at Harvard Business School. I bet you there's a bunch of entrepreneurs
in this room that want to start businesses.

I bet you none you want
to start a small business. I bet you all want to
build a big business. I bet you all understand that all big
businesses started as small businesses.

In fact, I think a company called Facebook
started in a dorm room at Harvard. I think it was one or two people
that started a small business

that became a big business. No one starts a small business because
they want to be a small business.

Everyone starts a small business
because they want to be a big business. How do small businesses
become big businesses?

They provide goods and they provide
services for people that they need. You paid a lot of
tuition to find that out.

Let me go back to
the major topic here. You guys keep arguing an
issue that I am confused

if you're arguing size matters,
regulation matters, or law matters.

Because you keep arguing that
people are breaking laws. If companies are breaking laws, I don't
think this side of the room was going to

advocate that companies should
be allowed to break laws. No companies should be
allowed to break laws. If you're arguing that we have
a bad regulatory environment,

we should fix the
regulatory environment. I'm very pro good,
smart regulation. I spent 26 years of my life in
a highly regulated industry.

We can really thrive in a
highly regulated industry. If that's what you're
arguing, go ahead. We're going to probably be
supportive of those arguments.

You're also making this argument that we know exactly what's
going to happen in the world. Like you said, you knew to break up
AT&T, and you knew to break up IBM.

Well, AT&T, the day you broke
it up was the exact same day that cell towers were
coming into this country.

I bet you none of these kids have
a landline in their room anymore. They don't know what
a landline looks like.

In fact, when my mine rings at
home, my kids look at it, like, what is that obsolete thing? So at the exact time you were
breaking up this dominant company,

it was becoming obsolete. People wrote the same thing
about Sears and Roebuck. Sears and Roebuck for those
of you that don't know,

was the Amazon of the
‘50s, ‘60s, ‘70s and ‘80s. It was the only place to buy the vast
majority of things in this country.

Kodak was one of the most
important companies in the world. Guess what?
Kodak got disintermediated

because they were the
only one that sold film. Believe it or not, you had to actually take
a picture in film and have it developed.

We have a long history in this
country of companies thriving,

and if they don't reinvent themselves,
they don't produce the product that people need,
they somehow disappear.

By the way, that's fine.
That's natural evolution. So I don't think we should be sitting
here and be smart enough to say

we know what the world's going to look
like in 5 years or 10 years or 15 years. In fact, there was a fairly substantial
research piece published yesterday,

talking, and I think the headline was
something like: Is Google The Next Kodak?

It was published yesterday, talking
about, is Google sticking to their ways because they only know
search, they know typing in?

And is ChatGPT and other AI engines
going to put them out of business?

A second point that I would make is,
you talk about this lack of competition. Best I can tell, there was about
400 billion that I can count

invested in startup
companies last year. I'm sure I'm missing a lot of it. That's 400 billion that if you want me to
document, I can document, 400 billion+.

I think there's a lot more than that
going in because of what's going on in AI. There's no shortage of startup capital.

There's no shortage of people looking to be
creative, looking to start new companies. There's no stifling of creativity going
on by these large, dominant companies.

In fact, these large, dominant
companies, in many respects, are providing startup capital
for many of the companies.

You talk about the Mag 7 in the
United States. Well, you know what? The competition for the Mag 7 is the
Mag 1, called the Chinese government.

If you know, in China most of the
companies are state owned enterprises. Look, we have seven companies trying
to compete against one company,

and one of them is
actually a car producer. The companies that are really more
important in the Elon Musk world

are probably the space company and The
Boring Company and other things like that. There's a lot of things going on here.
We know that the world changes quickly.

We should have an environment that
allows and facilitates for change. We should continue to provide an
environment where companies can thrive.

There is competition. You may not like the competition,
but I went through and counted in search engines, there's
at least 10 search engines.

You may not like them,
they may not be as good, but they clearly exist, and they're
there, and they're all making money.

They're all profitable today. All of these search engines
are profitable today. Thank you. All right.

We're now going to give each of the
debaters an opportunity to rebut sort of the part of your opponent's
arguments that made you most upset.

Tim, I'm going to ask you
to start on this side. Sure. I don't know
upset is the right word,

but I want to tackle
two questions here. Our opponents have taken the position
that suggests that companies,

the moment they become
obsolete, disappear, that the moment they're no longer
competitive, that's the end of them,

and that therefore, if a
monopoly or a tech company is no longer the best,
that it'll go away.

Now, there are tendencies in that
direction. I'm not going to deny that. But I want to suggest to you that
there is a storied history of companies

sticking around way past their
prime, and using anti-competitive

and illegal tactics to stay there
for very long periods of time. AT&T is a good example.

AT&T by the 1960s and ‘70s
had basically settled.

They were no longer
going to do much else. 8Bell Labs was doing
a lot of stuff, AT&T was happy with the
phone system the way it was.

Internet technologies came along, they were like, these are
never going to work, forget it. Only when the FCC started being tough
on AT&T, and only when we broke it out,

did you actually have the
explosion that led to the internet. I just think it's flat out wrong to say
that monopolies cannot defend themselves.

The number one way that monopolies
defend themselves is they turn to government for support and for
protection against competition.

I see many signs, I think the Silicon
Valley is turning towards government;

Elon Musk is the most
obvious example of it, and becoming more and more
like the defense industry.

The defense industry is still the same
damn companies from however long ago. You know, Lockheed Martin and
Boeing and a few other companies

are still the same companies that
have been around for decades, and I think they have very effectively
insulated themselves from competition.

I think the tech industry; information tech
would love to go in that same direction. I just deny, and I think the important
role that other sides of government play,

and even for itself, tech being too big,
is it needs to be an industry that is

constantly able to be
subject to competition, so that it actually gets better.
Otherwise, I think it'll stagnate.

That's the thing that I want
to point out most of all. Thank you. Jason, do you want
to rebut some of the specifics?

Sure. I want to bring
up really two points. A couple of years ago, in 2019 I did a
debate on the Upper West Side in New York

on whether the financial
system is safer. I went in with an
enormous amount of detail

on capital ratios and
leverage ratios and the like. My opponent said, “How could anything
be safe when Donald Trump is president?”

And the entire Upper West Side
audience voted against me. I would hate to see this
audience be as unsophisticated

as that Upper West Side audience. If this debate, as Jonathan
would like it to be, is,

do you think Elon Musk is a thoughtful,
diligent, hard working person who

unerringly does things in
the interests of the world? Yes or No,
I think I would lose this debate.

But his presence in this
government actually shows how much of a red herring this
is in linking it to big tech.

He's not someone who is a particular
monopolist in any important respect.

He is someone where most of his
companies are not fat and lazy; they're incredibly innovative.

He has a disproportionate amount of power
in our system with his $400 billion.

Guess what? Take away three quarters
of it, he only has $100 billion. That's still a decent amount of money,
enough that he could probably afford to

spend 25 million, or whatever it was, down
the drain on a judicial race in Wisconsin.

The issues that he has with
his power in the government are a set of really,
really important issues,

but they're not issues that are going
to be solved by antitrust policy. They're not issues that would be
solved by breaking up companies.

They're just not something
that we can deal with outside of things like the campaign
finance system, which gets to

how money translates into politics,
